Fields

View Source

ReplicationView

Create a replication view and specify the function to determine whether a database file is replicated to the local site.

Declaration
public EventHandler<ReplicationViewArgs> ReplicationView
Field Value
Type Description
System.EventHandler<ReplicationViewArgs>
Remarks

If it is null, the replication view is a full view and all database files are replicated to the local site. Otherwise it is a partial view and only some database files are replicated to the local site.

SetAcknowledgmentPolicy(RecordAcknowledgmentPolicy)

Specify the policy for how master and client sites will handle acknowledgment of replication messages which are necessary for "permanent" records.

Declaration
public void SetAcknowledgmentPolicy(RecordAcknowledgmentPolicy policy)
Parameters
Type Name Description
RecordAcknowledgmentPolicy policy
Remarks

View sites never send these acknowledgments and are not counted by any acknowledgment policy. The current implementation requires all sites in a replication group to configure the same acknowledgment policy.

Waiting for client acknowledgments is always limited by the ElectionTimeout. If an insufficient number of client acknowledgments have been received, then the master will invoke the event callback function, if set, with the ReplicationAckFailure value.

View Source

View Source

SetPriority(UInt32)

Sets the database environment's priority in replication group elections. A special value of 0 indicates that this environment cannot be a replication group master.

Declaration
public void SetPriority(uint priority)
Parameters
Type Name Description
System.UInt32 priority

The environment's priority.
Remarks

Each database environment included in a replication group must have a priority, which specifies a relative ordering among the different environments in a replication group. This ordering is a factor in determining which environment will be selected as a new master in case the existing master fails. Applications should specify environment priorities.

Priorities are an unsigned integer, but do not need to be unique throughout the replication group. A priority of 0 means the system can never become a master. Otherwise, larger valued priorities indicate a more desirable master. For example, if a replication group consists of three database environments, two of which are connected by an OC3 and the third of which is connected by a T1, the third database environment should be assigned a priority value which is lower than either of the other two.

Desirability of the master is first determined by the client having the most recent log records. Ties in log records are broken with the client priority. If both sites have the same log and the same priority, one is selected at random.

View Source

Remarks

View Source

Sync()

Forces synchronization to begin between master and client.

Declaration
public void Sync()
Remarks

If an application has configured delayed master synchronization, the application must synchronize explicitly (otherwise the client will remain out-of-date and will ignore all database changes forwarded from the replication group master).

This method may also be called after the client application learns a new master has been established via the ReplicationNewMaster flag.
